channel.title: NYT > Home Page
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: John Kerry, in a Final, Pointed Plea, Will Outline a Vision of Mideast Peace
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in September in New York. Mr. Netanyahu has clashed with Mr. Kerry and President Obama over settlements.
item.description: Mr. Kerry will use his remarks to confront Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel after bitterness over a United Nations resolution, a State Department official said.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Jerusalem Postpones Vote on New Housing Ahead of Speech by John Kerry
item.media:description: Construction this week in the settlement of Har Homa in Jerusalem.
item.description: A city government committee canceled a vote on permits for homes in East Jerusalem at the request of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Army Radio said.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Russians No Longer Dispute Olympic Doping Operation
item.media:description: The Russian Olympic Committee’s building in Moscow in 2015. Many of the athletes pictured in the building’s hallways have been implicated in this year’s doping scandal.
item.description: The officials ended their long denial but insisted that the state had no role in the doping and that it was not responsible for the institutionalized cheating.
item.dc:creator: REBECCA R. RUIZ

item.title: John Kerry, Russia, Carrie Fisher: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.media:description: “We must never repeat the horrors of war again,” Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, center-left, said on Tuesday, joining President Obama in Pearl Harbor. Mr. Abe offered condolences for the attack that drew the United States into World War II, but he did not apologize.
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: JONAH ENGEL BROMWICH

item.title: New York Today: New York Today: Valerie Goldfein, a New Yorker of the Year
item.media:description: After beating ovarian cancer, Valerie Goldfein is helping others do the same.
item.media:credit: Josh Ritchie for The New York Times
item.description: Wednesday: Honoring a model citizen, a midnight run through Central Park, and Good Riddance Day.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA S. LEVINE

item.title: Rick Perry, as Energy Secretary, May Be Pressed to Resume Nuclear Tests
item.media:description: Former Gov. Rick Perry of Texas was involved in helping set up a technology transfer program between Sandia National Laboratories, above, and the University of Texas.
item.media:credit: Sandia National Laboratories, via Associated Press
item.description: Some experts fear that testing the United States’ arsenal for the first time since 1992 would risk an arms race. But some worry about whether the weapons still work.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GLANZ

item.title: For the Trumps, ‘Made in U.S.A.’ May Be a Tricky Label to Stitch
item.media:description: Ivanka Trump items for sale at Saks Off Fifth in New York. Much of her company’s clothing line is manufactured overseas.
item.media:credit: Danny Ghitis for The New York Times
item.description: If President-elect Donald J. Trump makes good on the promise of punishing overseas companies, he will take aim at his own brand, and his daughter’s as well.
item.dc:creator: LAURA M. HOLSON and RACHEL ABRAMS

item.title: Hospitals in Safety Net Brace for Health Care Law’s Repeal
item.media:description: Philadelphia skyscrapers seen from the Temple section of North Philadelphia, near Temple University Hospital, one of the most impoverished areas in the nation.
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times
item.description: As the president-elect and Congress prepare to repeal the law, Temple University Hospital and others serving the poor expect harsh consequences.
item.dc:creator: ABBY GOODNOUGH
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

item.title: Trump Revives Defense of Charitable Foundation Amid Inquiry
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump at an event in Hershey, Pa., this month. Mr. Trump said on Saturday that he would shut down his charitable foundation.
item.description: The Donald J. Trump Foundation is under investigation by the New York attorney general after it indicated in tax filings that it may have broken rules.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN TWOHEY and STEVE EDER

item.title: Trump Inauguration Security Planners Brace for Wave of Protesters
item.media:description: Workers building viewing stands at the Capitol for President-elect Donald J. Trump’s inauguration.
item.description: Will an unusually rancorous election be capped off by an unusually tense inaugural week in Washington? Security officials worry it may be.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS FANDOS

item.title: Economic Policy: Faster Growth? Two Things Trump Supporters Won’t Like
item.media:description: Matt Grigsby, an engineer at Uber’s self-driving startup Otto, during a highway demonstration in San Francisco in August. Self-driving trucks would lift productivity — and put people out of work.
item.description: Productivity through automation and economic dynamism through immigration could hurt blue-collar workers.
item.dc:creator: NEIL IRWIN

item.title: Take a Ride with the Flying Scotsman
item.description: The Flying Scotsman, a beloved British steam engine, was recently renovated and came out of retirement.

item.title: Your Daily Mini Crossword
item.description: Solve a bite-size crossword in just a few minutes.

item.title: Carrie Fisher, Child of Hollywood and ‘Star Wars’ Royalty, Dies at 60
item.description: Ms. Fisher channeled her struggles with depression and substance abuse into fiercely comic works, including the novel “Postcards From the Edge.”
item.dc:creator: DAVE ITZKOFF

item.title: An Appraisal: Carrie Fisher, a Princess, a Rebel and a Brave Comic Voice
item.media:description: Carrie Fisher and Alec Baldwin in the “Rosemary’s Baby” episode of “30 Rock.”
item.description: She entered popular culture as a princess in peril and endures as something much more complicated and interesting.
item.dc:creator: A.O. SCOTT

item.title: Fans Tweet About Mental Illness to Honor Carrie Fisher
item.media:description: Carrie Fisher, in 2015 at the Screen Actors Guild Awards in Los Angeles. She was candid about her struggles with bipolar disorder and addiction.
item.description: Ms. Fisher was a staunch advocate for people with mental health problems and talked openly about her own struggles with bipolar disorder.
item.dc:creator: RYAN BURLESON and TARA PARKER-POPE

item.title: The Checkup: The Cough That Doesn’t Go Away
item.description: The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends against using over-the-counter cough medications in young children.
item.dc:creator: PERRI KLASS, M.D.

item.title: How to Back Up Your Social Media Feeds
item.description: If you don’t want to risk losing your photos and other memories stored online, consider making a copy of your account’s contents for safekeeping.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: 3 Men Made Millions by Hacking Merger Lawyers, U.S. Says
item.media:description: Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan.
item.description: The authorities in New York charged the Chinese citizens with trading shares of companies they illicitly learned were about to be purchased.
item.dc:creator: LESLIE PICKER

item.title: H.I.V. Cases Surpass a Million in Russia, but Little Is Done
item.media:description: Volunteers from the Andrey Rylkov Foundation distributing free needles, condoms and other supplies from a truck in Moscow.
item.media:credit: Max Avdeev for The New York Times
item.description: A combination of stigma and ignorance, a “family values” emphasis and government indifference have pushed H.I.V. to epidemic status.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Former Student Is Charged in Killings of Ex-Teacher and Their Son
item.media:description: Felicia Barahona and her son, Miguel, in an undated photo. They were found dead in their apartment in Upper Manhattan on Monday.
item.description: The tale of an illicit school relationship took a shocking turn on Tuesday when Isaac Duran Infante was charged with two counts of murder in the deaths of Felicia Barahona and their 4-year-old son.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN and AL BAKER

item.title: Tech Fix: Five Resolutions to Simplify Your Tech Life
item.description: Follow these tips to improve the maintenance of your passwords, devices and tech infrastructure. Also, shop smarter and reduce waste in 2017.
item.dc:creator: BRIAN X. CHEN

item.title: California Today
item.description: The news and stories that matter to Californians (and anyone else interested in the state). Sign up to get it by email.

item.title: Christmas Revelers Leave 16 Tons of Trash on Australian Beach
item.media:description: Bondi Beach in Sydney, Australia, on Christmas Day, where alcohol had already been prohibited. A raucous party down the shore at Coogee Beach has led to a total ban there, too, for the rest of the summer.
item.description: More than 10,000 people in a Sydney suburb made a huge mess, prompting a local council to ban alcohol on the beach for the rest of the Australian summer.
item.dc:creator: BRETT COLE

item.title: National Biotechnology Panel Faces New Conflict of Interest Questions
item.description: A committee is under fire for how its members were selected. Several have financial ties to biotech businesses, potentially giving short shrift to health and environmental worries.
item.dc:creator: STEPHANIE STROM
item.category: National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine

item.title: ‘Abandoned’ in New Jersey, Chris Christie Returns to a Changed Landscape
item.media:description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey spoke at a news conference about renovations to the State House Rotunda in Trenton, N.J., last month. The proposed renovations would cost $300 million at a time when the state has severe debt.
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.description: After months of humiliation on the campaign trail, the governor came home to find angry voters and a State Legislature unwilling to support his agenda.
item.dc:creator: KATE ZERNIKE and PATRICK McGEEHAN

item.title: Japanese Leader Offers Condolences in Visit to Pearl Harbor
item.description: Joining President Obama at the site of the attack that drew the United States into World War II, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said, “We must never repeat the horrors of war again.”
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: In Bahrain, Arabs and Jews Gather (and Dance) at a Hanukkah Celebration
item.description: Video of the gathering in the Muslim-majority monarchy, whose king has sanctioned celebrations of the Jewish holiday, appeared on YouTube.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: What in the World: Berlin Attraction Reveals an Uneasy Phenomenon: Hitler Sells
item.media:description: A replica of Hitler’s bunker in Berlin. It was built about a mile from the original site by a private company, Historiale, which also runs the Berlin Story Museum next door.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: A commercial firm has recreated the bunker where Hitler committed suicide in 1945.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: As U.K. Tightens Voting Rules, Critics Say Labour and the Poor Will Suffer
item.media:description: A polling station in London in June. Changes to voting rules will be used first for local elections in 18 areas in May 2018.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: The government announced plans to fight voter fraud by requiring voters to show official ID, tightening rules on absentee ballots and preventing political activists from handling such ballots.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: On Soccer: Bob Bradley Is Out in England. Round Up the Usual Replacements.
item.media:description: Bob Bradley on Oct. 22. “With the club going through such a tough time, we have to try and find the answers to get ourselves out of trouble,” Swansea City’s chairman said of his firing.
item.description: Bradley, the first American to lead a team in England’s Premier League, was fired by Swansea after winning only two of his 11 games with the club.
item.dc:creator: RORY SMITH

item.title: A Song for Bill de Blasio Sounds a Sour Note for Watchdogs
item.description: A video on the mayor’s City Hall Twitter account uses two Broadway stars to promote his accomplishments. Some say it is too much like a campaign ad.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: As Hopes for European Unity Dim, New E.U. Headquarters Are Glowing
item.media:description: The new European Union headquarters, the Europa, in Brussels. Ministers will move in shortly after the New Year and European Union leaders are expected to hold their first meeting there in March.
item.description: European leaders will meet in the bloc’s new home, an illuminated orb, in March, at a time when the union’s survival is being openly discussed.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: School Parade in Taiwan Featuring Swastikas and Nazis Unleashes Uproar
item.media:description: A cardboard tank at the Hsinchu Kuang-Fu High School in Hsinchu City, Taiwan.
item.description: The principal resigned after photographs and images went viral online, and after the unofficial diplomatic missions of Israel and Germany issued letters of protest.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS HORTON

item.title: Art That’s Disposable, but by No Means Throwaway
item.media:description: Ron Barron holding a screw he found on the Lower East Side of Manhattan last week. Mr. Barron, 78, creates art out of trash that he plucks from the streets of New York City.
item.media:credit: Joshua Bright for The New York Times
item.description: Ron Barron, 78, plucks trash from the streets of New York City and mails it home to Ohio, where he places his finds on a scanner and makes what are essentially large-scale prints.
item.dc:creator: JAMES BARRON

item.title: Vera Rubin, 88, Dies; Opened Doors in Astronomy, and for Women
item.media:description: Vera Rubin in the 1970s, when she mapped the distribution of mass in spiral galaxies by measuring how fast they rotated.
item.media:credit: Carnegie Institution of Washington, via Associated Press
item.description: Dr. Rubin, who was awarded the National Medal of Science in 1993, ushered in the cosmic realization that most of the universe is invisible.
item.dc:creator: DENNIS OVERBYE

item.title: A New Day for Gay Plays?
item.media:description: Front row, from left, Stephanie J. Block, Brandon Uranowitz, Andrew Rannells and Christian Borle; back row, from left, Betsy Wolfe and Tracie Thoms in “Falsettos.”
item.description: Old themes are still explored, but the context has changed.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES ISHERWOOD

item.title: City Kitchen: Small Luxuries for the New Year’s Eve Plate
item.media:description: Smoked trout and beet salad, with trout roe.
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.description: Humble ingredients, like bright golden beets, can be just as celebratory as caviar and truffles.
item.dc:creator: DAVID TANIS

item.title: In the Footsteps of Harry and Sally
item.description: “When Harry Met Sally” is a New York City holiday classic dressed up as a romance. Here’s where to recapture the magic.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GENZLINGER

item.title: The Neediest Cases: Giving Up ‘Mostly Everything’ to Care for His Wife
item.media:description: Abdou Travare and his wife, Ramata Travare, at home in the Bronx. He stopped working in 2013 to care for Mrs. Travare, who has diabetes, heart disease and dementia.
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.description: When Abdou Travare’s wife, Ramata, learned she had dementia, he quit his job to be by her side. His savings have dwindled, and he has struggled to pay the rent.
item.dc:creator: JOHN OTIS
item.category: Catholic Charities Archdiocese of New York
New York Times Neediest Cases Fund
